name: Algorave
description: Generative dancefloor-oriented music produced live via algorithms.

name: Binaural Beats
description: Auditory illusions created when two different frequencies are played simultaneously in separate ears.

name: Bit Music
description: Created by sound chips, cards, and sequencers found in video game consoles, personal computers, and arcade machines, as well as synthesizers emulating these sounds.

children.name: Chiptune
children.description: Used primarily in the 1980s within the context of 8-bit Video Game Music, combining simple synthesized waveforms and noise in a compositionally limited but overtly melodic style.

children.name: FM Synthesis
children.description: Sound synthesis that combines the simple waveforms of Chiptune with modulating oscillators to create a bouncier synthesizer sound that would be used in arcade cabinets and home video game consoles like the Sega Mega Drive/Genesis in the late 1980s.

children.name: MIDI Music
children.description: Intended for real-time sequenced playback via MIDI protocol on MIDI devices and used primarily in 1990s PC Video Game Music, arranger keyboards and karaoke.

children.name: Black MIDI
children.description: Consists of extremely dense MIDI piano compositions, impossible to play on physical instruments.

children.name: Sequencer & Tracker
children.description: Composed for early home computer and game consoles from the late 1980s to the late 1990s, primarily for video game soundtracks.

children.name: 16-bit
children.description: Created using video game consoles with audio hardware using 16-bit audio samples, most notably the Super Nintendo Entertainment System.

children.name: Tracker Music
children.description: Vertical text-based step-sequencer software sampler music in the first and second gen module formats like .MOD, .MED, .S3M, .XM and .IT.

children.name: Doskpop
children.description: Сombines Spacesynth composition with tracker techniques and the traditional demoscene sound.

name: Bitpop
description: Fuses Bit Music with additional synths, beats, guitars and modern production values, emphasizing highly catchy melodies and relatively fast tempos.

name: Celtic Electronica
description: Fusion of Celtic Folk Music with various types of Electronic Dance Music.

name: Chillout
description: Broad category of many relaxed styles of Electronic music which predominantly draw influence from Electronic Dance Music subgenres and Ambient.

children.name: Ambient Dub
children.description: Takes cues from Ambient and Dub reggae, featuring the atmosphere of the former and the Jamaican-style basslines, percussion, and psychedelic production techniques of the latter.

children.name: Ambient House
children.description: Primarily British genre developed in the 1990s with beats, synthesizers, and vocals in styles similar to House, treated with effects that are often described as "dream-like" or "chilled out".

children.name: Ambient Trance
children.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s mainly in the form of Chillout remixes of Trance tracks; incorporates its arpeggiated synthesizer sound into Downtempo and Ambient contexts.

children.name: Balearic Beat
children.description: Variety of relaxed, laid-back music that originates from the Balearic Islands off the coast of Spain, and particularly the club scene in Ibiza.

children.name: Barber Beats
children.description: Borrows elements from Downtempo, Trip Hop, and Instrumental Hip Hop; emulates 1990s and 2000s Chillout music.

children.name: Downtempo
children.description: Atmospheric and groove-based with relaxed tempos and mellow beats.

children.name: Trip Hop
children.description: Evokes a surreal, trippy, dreamy, and sometimes dark atmosphere with offbeat turntable scratches, light vocal melodies, and Hip Hop-influenced beats.

children.name: Psybient
children.description: Heavy influence from Psytrance and Goa Trance incorporated in an atmospheric Ambient context.

name: Digital Fusion
description: Incorporates the hardware-limited sounds of Chiptune and other Bit Music into compositions drawing on Jazz, Cinematic Classical, progressive music, and other Electronic styles, sometimes augmented with live instrumentation.

name: Drift Phonk
description: Busy, noisy production inspired by lo-fi Memphis Rap; frequently features 808 cowbell melodies and chopped, compressed samples.

children.name: Phonk House
children.description: Merges Drift Phonk's nocturnal atmospheres, cowbell melodies, vocal samples, and energetic production, with House rhythms and tempos, characterized by a banging and upbeat sound.

name: Dungeon Synth
description: Focuses on evoking epic and atmospheric soundscapes commonly associated with fantasy and medieval settings through the usage of synthesizers, keyboards, and drum machines.

children.name: Comfy Synth
children.description: Calm, peaceful and soothing sounds, as well as nostalgic, sentimental, or childish atmospheres and aesthetics; often incorporates wholesome themes while utilizing lo-fi or hazy recordings and influences from New Age.

children.name: Winter Synth
children.description: Cold, minimalistic, and repetitive soundscapes, commonly invoking imagery of winter.

name: Electroacoustic
description: Manipulation and processing of sound sources to create atmospheric pieces.

children.name: Acousmatic Music
children.description: Fixed-media Electroacoustic music designed to be reproduced by multiple loudspeakers without the presence of instrumentalists and visual cues.

children.name: EAI
children.description: Slow paced, physical, textured aesthetic - often created using unconventional instruments processed through a computer.

children.name: Musique concrète
children.description: Manipulation of recorded sounds, mostly Field Recordings, natural sounds, and real-world noises, as a process of abstracting "concrete" sounds, or "sound objects", from their acoustic origins.

name: Electro-Industrial
description: Formed in the late 1980s and early 1990s; grew out of a combination of EBM and Industrial.

children.name: Dark Electro
children.description: Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, combining EBM beats with the abrasiveness of old school Industrial but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.

children.name: Aggrotech
children.description: Based on the dark atmosphere of Dark Electro, typically characterized by more aggressive Hardcore [EDM]-influenced beats and harsh/distorted vocals.

name: Electronic Dance Music
description: Broad category for subgenres mainly derived from Disco, featuring Electronic sounds, synthesizers, drum machines and varying BPM ranges.

children.name: Artcore
children.description: Combines an eclectic mix of Electronic Dance Music genres with the instrumentation and melodic stylings of genres like Cinematic Classical for a maximalist and emotional sound.

children.name: Balani Show
children.description: Emerged in the late 1990s in Mali; peaks at around 170BPM and prominently features looping, cut-up balafon samples.

children.name: Balearic Beat
children.description: Variety of relaxed, laid-back music that originates from the Balearic Islands off the coast of Spain, and particularly the club scene in Ibiza.

children.name: Bérite Club
children.description: Originated in the underground club scene of Paris in the mid-to-late 2010s, drawing on a variety of international club styles for its combination of prominent and erratic drum programming with freezing and looping chopped-up samples.

children.name: Breakbeat
children.description: An umbrella of affiliated Electronic Dance Music styles broadly characterized by prominent syncopated drum patterns (called breakbeats) that emerged from Breakbeat Hardcore's initial influence, not including styles directly related to Drum and Bass and Jungle.

children.name: Acid Breaks
children.description: Incorporates prominent "squelching", resonant low pass filter sounds typical to Acid House, and often other "trippy" effects into intense, syncopated, broken rhythms in the tempos of 110-150 BPM.

children.name: Baltimore Club
children.description: Drew on the "booty bass" syncopation of Miami Bass, combined with Breakbeat rhythms around 130 BPM and chopped up vocal samples as found in Ghetto House.

children.name: Big Beat
children.description: Popular in Britain during the late 1990s, driven by edited breakbeats and prominent basslines.

children.name: Breakbeat Hardcore
children.description: Originated from the combination of sampled breakbeats and energetic rhythms with the "rave" influences set by early-1990s Techno and Acid House, including upbeat "stab" riffing and sample-based production.

children.name: Darkside
children.description: Dark atmosphere and fast rhythms; served as a forerunner of Drum and Bass.

children.name: Hardcore Breaks
children.description: Revival of Breakbeat Hardcore which emerged in the 2000s, bringing in modern influences and production techniques.

children.name: Breakbeat Kota
children.description: Indonesian style that slows down the syncopated rhythms of Funkot to moderate tempos around 130 BPM.

children.name: Jungle Dutch
children.description: A style of Breakbeat Kota with the high-pitched synth leads of Dutch House and the frantic "tribal" rhythms of Jungle Terror.

children.name: Florida Breaks
children.description: Developed during the mid-1990s, combining major influences of Hip Hop derivatives such as Miami Bass and Electro along with elements of 1990s Electronic Dance Music genres like House or Techno.

children.name: Nu Skool Breaks
children.description: Developed in the late 1990s and early 2000s; combines elements from Drum and Bass, UK Garage, and Techno with breakbeat.

children.name: Progressive Breaks
children.description: Derivative of Progressive House that incorporates its lush, melodic synth leads and atmospheres into Breakbeat's syncopated and broken rhythms.

children.name: Psybreaks
children.description: Uses Psytrance-derived sound design, such as squelchy sounds and psychedelic effects.

children.name: West Coast Breaks
children.description: Combines the earlier breakbeats of Hip Hop and early Breakbeat or even Miami Bass, with various 1990s Electronic Dance Music genres like Trance and Techno.

children.name: Broken Beat
children.description: Syncopated rhythm patterns arrived at through Drum and Bass programming techniques; originally developed by artists hailing from Techno, House, drum and bass, and Hip Hop backgrounds.

children.name: Bubblegum Bass
children.description: Originated in the early 2010s, exaggerating the cutest and most feminine parts of 2000s Pop and combining them with bouncy, plastic synths over rhythms and sounds derived from a variety of contemporary club styles.

children.name: Bubbling
children.description: Originating in the Netherlands in the late 1980s, fusing sped-up Dancehall with Dutch Antillean music and contemporary Dutch rave.

children.name: Budots
children.description: Originated from the southern Philippines; notable for its distinct high-pitched synth hooks.

children.name: Coupé-décalé
children.description: Bass-heavy and minimal style of Ivorian popular dance music, drawing heavily from Zouglou and Congolese rhythms.

children.name: Cruise
children.description: Fast-paced Nigerian dance style, utilising humorous samples.

children.name: Dariacore
children.description: Focused on prominent vocal samples, chaotic and distorted production, hard and noisy basslines reminiscent of Future Bass, elements of Mashup, Nightcore and Jersey Club, and humorous meme clips.

children.name: Deconstructed Club
children.description: Emerged in the 2010s as the hybridization of diverse Electronic Dance Music genres with an abrasive Post-Industrial sound.

children.name: Digital Cumbia
children.description: Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.

children.name: Drum and Bass
children.description: Typified by fast, syncopated breakbeat patterns (often sampled or programmed) with prominent basslines, commonly within the 160-180 BPM range.

children.name: Atmospheric Drum and Bass
children.description: Prominent in the mid-1990s, distinguished by its use of faster, de-emphasized breakbeats and a greater focus on more melodic elements like slow, warm basslines and atmospheric melodies inspired by Ambient and Ambient House.

children.name: Dancefloor Drum and Bass
children.description: Emerged in the late 2000s and early 2010s as a form of simpler, lighter and more melodic Drum and Bass in comparison to many of the drum and bass genres which preceded it.

children.name: Darkstep
children.description: Hard, uptempo and uses heavy breakbeats, Post-Industrial-influenced sound design, and horror movie samples to create a sinister, claustrophobic atmosphere.

children.name: Crossbreed
children.description: Harsh and dense mixture of Darkstep with Hardcore [EDM] developed in the late 2000s.

children.name: Skullstep
children.description: Repetitious, aggressive, off-beat rhythms often programmed using distorted, harsh, and noisy percussion that usually resembles clangy "pots and pans", machine gun-like snares.

children.name: Drumfunk
children.description: Focuses on complex drum beats made to emulate live recordings.

children.name: Drumstep
children.description: Dancefloor-friendly, loud, and heavy combination of the drum programming of Jump-Up with the half-time tempo and midrange LFO wobble of Brostep.

children.name: Dubwise Drum and Bass
children.description: Implementing Reggae and Dub influences, usually vocal dubs, delay effects, and reggae instrumentation, with the clean production and rhythms of post-2000s styles.

children.name: Footwork Jungle
children.description: Combining Footwork's archetypal percussion, skittering drum fills, handclaps, and syncopated rhythms, with Drum and Bass drum programming and breakbeats, merging the two into unconventional, frantic drumming and dense, off-kilter rhythms.

children.name: Halftime
children.description: Offshoot of Drum and Bass (mainly Neurofunk) characterized by off-kilter rhythms playing at around 80-85 BPM (half of normal DnB pace), influenced by Dubstep, Wonky, Trap [EDM], and Hip Hop.

children.name: Hardstep
children.description: Very compressed and sparse drumming, extensive use of kick drums and gritty, minimalistic production style with emphasis on simple, deep, modulated bass patterns.

children.name: Jazzstep
children.description: Combines the rhythm and speed of Drum and Bass with the melodies, composition, and instrumentation of Jazz.

children.name: Jump-Up
children.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s, characterized by loud "wobbling" basslines, simpler drum loops, and a light-hearted and warm sound.

children.name: Jungle
children.description: Developed in the early 1990s from Breakbeat Hardcore, featuring rapid, chaotic-sounding breakbeats and strong basslines; known as the forerunner of most Drum and Bass styles.

children.name: Ragga Jungle
children.description: Developed in the early 1990s in London, combining Jungle breakbeats with heavy influence from Ragga.

children.name: Liquid Drum and Bass
children.description: Lush and warm variant of Drum and Bass developed in the early 2000s, using polished, smooth production, Funk and Soul samples and occasionally incorporating live instrumentation.

children.name: Sambass
children.description: Combines Drum and Bass tempos and drum patterns, in addition to its Funk and Soul influences, with various styles of Brazilian Music.

children.name: Minimal Drum and Bass
children.description: Drum and Bass which strips down the sound as far as it can go without wholly ceasing to be drum and bass.

children.name: Neurofunk
children.description: Focuses on technical songwriting with warped, complex bass sounds, distorted and modulated synths (often with repeated stabs over the basslines), and dark but clean production.

children.name: Techstep
children.description: Futuristic, dark, and gritty sound; quantized and compressed drum breaks, distorted bass lines, and a focus on a sci-fi atmosphere and sampling sources.

children.name: Trancestep
children.description: Combination of Trance melodies and structure with the breakbeats, fast tempos, and rolling basslines of Drum and Bass.

children.name: Dubstep
children.description: Characterized by half-time syncopated and sparse beats set around 140 BPM with heavy sub-basses; emerged in South London in the early 2000s.

children.name: Brostep
children.description: Offshoot of Dubstep which replaces its sub-bass-oriented sound with an emphasis on catchy or aggressive mid-range melodies.

children.name: Briddim
children.description: Combining the kick-clap rhythms and syncopation of Riddim with Brostep sound design.

children.name: Colour Bass
children.description: Combines aggressive wobbling basses with the euphoric drops of Melodic Dubstep and Future Bass.

children.name: Deathstep
children.description: Darker, heavier form of Brostep that uses "machine gun" basses, atonal synths, and elements from genres like Death Metal and Metalcore.

children.name: Drumstep
children.description: Dancefloor-friendly, loud, and heavy combination of the drum programming of Jump-Up with the half-time tempo and midrange LFO wobble of Brostep.

children.name: Tearout [Brostep]
children.description: Heavy and distorted, closely affiliated with Deathstep and other styles of Brostep.

children.name: Chillstep
children.description: Relaxed Dubstep influenced by Downtempo and Ambient.

children.name: Dungeon Sound
children.description: Commonly features dark textures, spatial production, and midrange basses.

children.name: Melodic Dubstep
children.description: Melodious, tuneful drops, rich, lush synth leads, powerful stretched chords, and light and harmonious sound design.

children.name: Purple Sound
children.description: Emerged in the late 2000s out of the Dubstep scene of the time, incorporating synth leads and basslines inspired by 1980s Synth Funk and 1990s G-Funk, and Video Game Music, into a rhythmic palette mostly derived from dubstep and Grime.

children.name: Riddim
children.description: Heavy use of repetition and wet, metallic sound design.

children.name: Future Riddim
children.description: Melodic and futuristic style inspired by Future Bass, and to a lesser extent Colour Bass and Melodic Dubstep.

children.name: Tearout
children.description: Emerged in the late 2000s, characterized by a gritty, aggressive sound and closely affiliated with early, deep Dubstep.

children.name: East Coast Club
children.description: Group of club styles from the US East Coast that combines Miami Bass rhythms with influence from Breakbeat and Ghetto House.

children.name: Baltimore Club
children.description: Drew on the "booty bass" syncopation of Miami Bass, combined with Breakbeat rhythms around 130 BPM and chopped up vocal samples as found in Ghetto House.

children.name: Jersey Club
children.description: Emerged in Newark in the late 2000s; features fast tempos, hard kicks, and less prominent breakbeats.

children.name: Philly Club
children.description: Builds on Baltimore Club with a faster tempo and sometimes influences from more modern genres like Trap [EDM].

children.name: EBM
children.description: Melodic and beat-driven Electronic Dance Music take on Post-Industrial that developed in the 1980s.

children.name: Dark Electro
children.description: Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, combining EBM beats with the abrasiveness of old school Industrial but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.

children.name: Aggrotech
children.description: Based on the dark atmosphere of Dark Electro, typically characterized by more aggressive Hardcore [EDM]-influenced beats and harsh/distorted vocals.

children.name: Futurepop
children.description: Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.

children.name: New Beat
children.description: Underground dance music which originated in Belgium around 1987, tending to resemble slower, harder EBM.

children.name: Electro
children.description: Syncopated rhythms programmed on the Roland TR-808 drum machine, often resembling Funk breaks, along with simple funky basslines.

children.name: Skweee
children.description: Originated among Nordic artists in the mid-2000s, inspired by elements of Synth Funk, Hip Hop, and IDM.

children.name: Electroclash
children.description: Draws from 1980s styles such as Electro, New Wave, and Electro-Disco combined with Techno, resulting in minimal, throbbing beats and basslines, buzzing synthesizer parts, vocoders and often monotone, half-spoken, half-sung vocals.

children.name: Electro-Disco
children.description: Disco instrumentation is largely - if not entirely - replaced by synthesizers and augmented with futuristic elements such as the vocoder.

children.name: Hi-NRG
children.description: Emerged in the late 1970s and quickly became the most popular form of Electronic Dance Music in the LGBT club scenes of San Francisco and New York, characterized by its uptempo, high-energy sound.

children.name: Italo-Disco
children.description: Produced primarily in Italy and is characterized by the use of synthesizers, drum machines, and sometimes vocoders to create a mechanical, Electronic version of Disco with futuristic atmosphere.

children.name: Spacesynth
children.description: Highly melodic, often instrumental futuristic strain, formed under the heavy influence of Space Disco, Progressive Electronic and, later, early Eurobeat.

children.name: Doskpop
children.description: Сombines Spacesynth composition with tracker techniques and the traditional demoscene sound.

children.name: Space Disco
children.description: Emerged in Europe in the mid-to-late 1970s, characterized by layers of oscillating synth, space-oriented sound effects, and a futuristic sound inspired by contemporary sci-fi media.

children.name: Electro latino
children.description: Mixes elements of Merengue and Reggaetón with polished production from mainstream House subgenres; often shares traits with Latin Pop, having anthemic melodies and verse-chorus structures.

children.name: Electro Swing
children.description: Upbeat, energetic style that splices Swing with Electronic Dance Music, looking to recapture the atmosphere of late 1920s to mid-1940s Jazz within a more updated club-friendly medium.

children.name: Eurobeat
children.description: Fast-paced with roots in Hi-NRG and Italo-Disco; became mainly popular in Japan in the 1990s.

children.name: Eurodance
children.description: Takes elements of Euro-Disco, House, Techno, and Hi-NRG while featuring on-beat kick, hi-hat and snare sounds at around 110 to 150 bpm.

children.name: Bubblegum Dance
children.description: Playful, childlike style with a Bubblegum-like atmosphere that often incorporates high-pitched, light-hearted, and usually female-fronted vocals.

children.name: Italo Dance
children.description: Appeared in the 1990s after the decline of Italo-Disco, featuring rhythmic influence from that genre.

children.name: Flex Dance Music
children.description: Largely instrumental; infused with Electronic Dance Music elements.

children.name: Footwork
children.description: Extensive use of drum fills, tom drums, handclaps, and snares within fast-paced, highly syncopated beats not bound to a 4/4 kick rhythm.

children.name: Footwork Jungle
children.description: Combining Footwork's archetypal percussion, skittering drum fills, handclaps, and syncopated rhythms, with Drum and Bass drum programming and breakbeats, merging the two into unconventional, frantic drumming and dense, off-kilter rhythms.

children.name: Freestyle
children.description: Electro-influenced; developed in Latino communities in New York and Miami in the 1980s, especially dominated by Latin Freestyle and its Latin influences.

children.name: Latin Freestyle
children.description: Displays a heavy influence of Hispanic American Music alongside the Disco, Hip Hop, and Electro influences of Freestyle.

children.name: Funkot
children.description: Fast-paced Indonesian form of Electronic Dance Music that combines Eurodance and Trance synths with the syncopated rhythm from Dangdut koplo.

children.name: Breakbeat Kota
children.description: Indonesian style that slows down the syncopated rhythms of Funkot to moderate tempos around 130 BPM.

children.name: Jungle Dutch
children.description: A style of Breakbeat Kota with the high-pitched synth leads of Dutch House and the frantic "tribal" rhythms of Jungle Terror.

children.name: Future Bass
children.description: Woozy, detuned synthesizers, 7th chords, harsh basslines, syncopated percussion with fast-paced hi-hats and a melodic, carefree atmosphere.

children.name: Kawaii Future Bass
children.description: "Cute" style of Future Bass rooted in anime and video game culture; emerged in Japan in the mid-2010s.

children.name: Future Rave
children.description: Emerged in the late 2010s by combining the mainstage EDM approach with influences from then-popular forms of Techno and old-school Trance/rave-inspired grooves and atmospheres.

children.name: Ghettotech
children.description: Fuses the syncopation and synthesized sounds of Electro and Detroit Techno with the cut-up samples of Ghetto House and fast rhythms of Miami Bass.

children.name: Glitch Hop [EDM]
children.description: Tempos around 100-110 BPM, swung, bouncy drum patterns, and a focus on upbeat, danceable drops and buildups.

children.name: Ghetto Funk
children.description: Rich sampling, drawing from classic Hip Hop as well as from Funk and Soul, and strong midtempo break grooves.

children.name: Neurohop
children.description: Features the complex bass of Neurofunk and a frantic and mechanical sound design.

children.name: Grime
children.description: UK Garage-derived production style characterized by dark, fast-paced, often aggressive beats that commonly features fast-paced MCing.

children.name: Neo-Grime
children.description: Mixes Wave with Grime and other forms of UK Electronic music.

children.name: Weightless
children.description: Typically instrumental, leftfield Grime style characterized by sparse, "weightless" percussion and spectral, atmospheric production.

children.name: Hardcore [EDM]
children.description: Umbrella term for a wide variety of extremely fast-paced, energetic Electronic Dance Music styles that have been developed since the early 1990s.

children.name: Acidcore
children.description: Developed out of the 1990s Acid Techno scene utilizing its prominence of "acid" TB-303 bassline sequences into more intense rhythms derived from earlier Hardcore [EDM], Gabber and Trance music.

children.name: Belgian Techno
children.description: Early form of Hardcore [EDM], resulting from the further evolution of New Beat due to the strong influence of Techno and EBM.

children.name: Breakbeat Hardcore
children.description: Originated from the combination of sampled breakbeats and energetic rhythms with the "rave" influences set by early-1990s Techno and Acid House, including upbeat "stab" riffing and sample-based production.

children.name: Darkside
children.description: Dark atmosphere and fast rhythms; served as a forerunner of Drum and Bass.

children.name: Hardcore Breaks
children.description: Revival of Breakbeat Hardcore which emerged in the 2000s, bringing in modern influences and production techniques.

children.name: Breakcore
children.description: Mixes Hardcore [EDM] with cut-up, complex, and frequently noisy breakbeats at very high tempos inspired by Jungle and Drum and Bass, often with heavy use of sampling.

children.name: Lolicore
children.description: Heavily distorted or high-pitched anime vocal samples and complex cut-up breakbeats with extreme tempos.

children.name: Mashcore
children.description: Sampling, particularly from Pop and Electronic Dance Music, as well as playful melodies, hard kicks, and the typical breakcore breakbeats.

children.name: Raggacore
children.description: Combines Breakcore with elements from Ragga and Dancehall.

children.name: Crossbreed
children.description: Harsh and dense mixture of Darkstep with Hardcore [EDM] developed in the late 2000s.

children.name: Deathchant Hardcore
children.description: Took shape in the UK in the late 1990s and early 2000s, characterized by rapid rhythms with Gabber-influenced kicks, frequent use of breakbeats and Hip Hop-inspired sampling.

children.name: Digital Hardcore
children.description: High-tempo fusion of Hardcore Punk and Electronic, combining harsh vocals and electric guitars of the former with electronic instruments.

children.name: Doomcore
children.description: Often somber and contemplative in mood, a feature achieved by the common use of long-stretched ambient pads, and sometimes even samples of screaming and other "spooky" sounds.

children.name: Freeform Hardcore
children.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s, combining fast and hard-hitting rhythms with heavy influence from the synthesizers of Trance.

children.name: Frenchcore
children.description: Off-beat, bouncy rhythmic patterns and tempos around the 200 BPM range.

children.name: Gabber
children.description: Fast-paced and energetic, often in the 160-220 BPM range, with a hallmark of a distinctive distorted kick sound.

children.name: Nu Style Gabber
children.description: Emerged near the end of the 1990s; deeper, more harmonic bassdrums with constant use of supersaw melodies, breakdown sections and slower tempos closer to the 150-180 BPM range.

children.name: Happy Hardcore
children.description: Emerged in the 1990s from the UK Breakbeat Hardcore scene; characterized by saccharine vocals, uplifting piano riffs and spacey effects, gradually developing to emphasize extremely fast-paced four-on-the-floor beats.

children.name: Bouncy Techno
children.description: Average tempo of 160 to 180 BPM, four-on-the-floor beats, melodic and repetitive synth melodies, drums with hard kicks, short breaks, progressive stomping rhythms, and offbeat notes.

children.name: UK Hardcore
children.description: Four-on-the-floor beat around 175 BPM, thick, prominent basslines, and uplifting synth leads, with a cleaner and more accessible sound than other forms of Hardcore [EDM].

children.name: Powerstomp
children.description: Prominent, "stomping", and slightly distorted kick, relentless, repetitive reverse basses on the offbeats (borrowed from Hardstyle) that drive the tracks, giving the genre its distinct energetic sound, and cacophonous, noisy riffs and synth leads.

children.name: Hardtek
children.description: Modern hard dance-influenced version of the "tribecore" sound featuring deep alternating basses and festival EDM-influenced drops.

children.name: Raggatek
children.description: Influenced by Reggae, Ragga and Dancehall, combining half-time instrumental sections with Hardtek's fast four-on-the-floor rhythms, as well as vocal samples, clean basslines and skank rhythms.

children.name: Industrial Hardcore
children.description: Fuses the sonic palettes and aesthetics of Industrial & Noise with the intense rhythms of Gabber, Speedcore, Doomcore and other subsequent styles.

children.name: J-core
children.description: More energetic and eclectic form of Japanese Hardcore [EDM].

children.name: Speedcore
children.description: Exceedingly fast tempos, frequently above 300 BPM, and often aggressive themes and samples.

children.name: Extratone
children.description: Often sounds like a buzz or hum due to being set to at least 1000 BPM.

children.name: Splittercore
children.description: Faster version of Speedcore with BPM ranging from around 600 through 1000.

children.name: Terrorcore
children.description: Utilizes rhythms from earlier Gabber with a faster BPM (usually no more than 300) and darker approach.

children.name: Uptempo Hardcore
children.description: Utilizes lo-fi production, harsh kicks, and elements borrowed from Rawstyle and other gritty Hardcore [EDM] styles while usually sitting at around 185-220 BPM.

children.name: Hard Dance
children.description: Umbrella term for EDM mainly developed out of Hard Trance and UK Hard House; usually characterized by fast tempos, hard kick drums and a "bouncy" syncopated groove.

children.name: Hardstyle
children.description: Hard, four-on-the-floor kick drums, fast tempo around 150 BPM, reverse bass and harsh, distorted synths.

children.name: Dubstyle
children.description: Characterized by the incorporation of the half-time rhythms and wobbly basslines of Dubstep.

children.name: Euphoric Hardstyle
children.description: Melodic, more lighthearted, and accessible Hardstyle.

children.name: Psystyle
children.description: Prominent Psytrance influences, especially the basslines and energy of mainstream psytrance.

children.name: Rawstyle
children.description: Incorporates earlier Hardstyle and Hardcore [EDM] influences into the sound of 2010s hardstyle, creating a distinctly harsh, simplistic, raw, and dark sound, with fast BPM.

children.name: Rawphoric
children.description: Combines raw harsh kicks with the uplifting melodies of Euphoric Hardstyle.

children.name: Hardtek
children.description: Modern hard dance-influenced version of the "tribecore" sound featuring deep alternating basses and festival EDM-influenced drops.

children.name: Raggatek
children.description: Influenced by Reggae, Ragga and Dancehall, combining half-time instrumental sections with Hardtek's fast four-on-the-floor rhythms, as well as vocal samples, clean basslines and skank rhythms.

children.name: Hard Trance
children.description: Rave-oriented form of Trance infusing its atmospheres with faster, thumping rhythms and strong melodic / bassline sections, initially spawning out of the first wave in early-1990s Western Europe.

children.name: Jumpstyle
children.description: Heavy, distorted 909 beat popular in European countries like Belgium and the Netherlands in the 2000s.

children.name: Lento violento
children.description: Features a "slow and violent" sound between 70-120 BPM with hard kicks inspired by Hardcore [EDM] and Hardstyle.

children.name: NRG
children.description: Derived from UK Hard House; featuring darker, more anthemic Trance beats and a tempo of 155-165 BPM.

children.name: UK Hardcore
children.description: Four-on-the-floor beat around 175 BPM, thick, prominent basslines, and uplifting synth leads, with a cleaner and more accessible sound than other forms of Hardcore [EDM].

children.name: Powerstomp
children.description: Prominent, "stomping", and slightly distorted kick, relentless, repetitive reverse basses on the offbeats (borrowed from Hardstyle) that drive the tracks, giving the genre its distinct energetic sound, and cacophonous, noisy riffs and synth leads.

children.name: UK Hard House
children.description: Defined by offbeat bass patterns, compressed 909-style drums, buildup-drop structures, hoover sounds, and tempos between 120 and 155 BPM.

children.name: Scouse House
children.description: Features an upbeat and energetic sound often described as being "bouncy", influenced somewhat by Happy Hardcore.

children.name: Hardbass
children.description: Bouncy hard bass beats, fast tempo, usually 150-175 BPM, and occasional lyrics or rapping.

children.name: Speed House
children.description: Mixes busy, dirty sound design and intense drums derived from Bass House with fast tempos from 140-160 BPM, pumping basslines, and other UK Hard House influences.

children.name: Hard Drum
children.description: Highly percussive, syncopated rhythms, influences from global contemporary genres, and lack of melodic elements, with a tempo lingering between 130 BPM.

children.name: Hardvapour
children.description: Influenced by Hardcore [EDM] and Techno and made in response to the Vaporwave movement.

children.name: Hardwave
children.description: Harder, festival-oriented offshoot of Wave, combining its "reese" basses and icy synths with Trap [EDM] drum patterns, build-up-drop structures, and fuller sound influenced by Trance and Hardstyle.

children.name: House
children.description: Large, hugely popular group of related Electronic Dance Music styles, initially developing from Disco in the early 1980s.

children.name: Acid House
children.description: Emerged in the mid-1980s, characterised by repetitive basslines created with the distinctive modulated "squelching" sound of the Roland TB-303 synthesiser.

children.name: Afro House
children.description: Emerged by fusing Deep House with Southern African Music, characterized by hypnotizing drum patterns of shakers and congas, often sampled African vocals or soulful original features, and spiritual, organic, melodic atmosphere.

children.name: Amapiano
children.description: House from South Africa deriving from previous popular genres including Gqom, Kwaito, and Deep House.

children.name: Afropiano
children.description: Blends the easy-going, poppy, and melodic Afrobeats sound and rhythms with major Amapiano elements, like lush, jazzy, and laid-back atmospheres often featuring light piano chords.

children.name: Ambient House
children.description: Primarily British genre developed in the 1990s with beats, synthesizers, and vocals in styles similar to House, treated with effects that are often described as "dream-like" or "chilled out".

children.name: Ballroom
children.description: Emerging from the predominantly Black and LGBT Harlem ballroom culture, it is characterized by hard-hitting rhythms, generally improvised vocals and staccato scatting by MCs known as commentators, and a distinctive crash sample.

children.name: Baltimore Club
children.description: Drew on the "booty bass" syncopation of Miami Bass, combined with Breakbeat rhythms around 130 BPM and chopped up vocal samples as found in Ghetto House.

children.name: Bass House
children.description: Busy, punchy percussion, prominent basslines and dirty, distorted synths resembling other bass music genres, with influences including Brostep, Fidget House, Bassline, Speed Garage, and Tech House.

children.name: Speed House
children.description: Mixes busy, dirty sound design and intense drums derived from Bass House with fast tempos from 140-160 BPM, pumping basslines, and other UK Hard House influences.

children.name: Bassline
children.description: Strong emphasis on intricate basslines as well as four-on-the-floor beat patterns.

children.name: Big Room House
children.description: Very energetic, festival-focused EDM genre characterized by heavily reverberated sound, trance-inspired anthemic breakdowns, intense build-ups, four-on-the-floor beat focused on a strong kick and simple, minimalistic, drop melodies.

children.name: Brazilian Bass
children.description: Originated in the 2010s in Brazil, taking influences from Deep House and Tech House, characterized by deep, punchy basslines making use of detuning and filtering effects.

children.name: Mega funk
children.description: Blends funk vocal performances with production derived from mainstage 2010s house genres like Brazilian Bass and Slap House.

children.name: Slap House
children.description: Taking influences from Brazilian Bass and Future House, characterized by prominent, "bouncy" bassline and simple, upbeat melodies.

children.name: Bubbling House
children.description: Developed in the Netherlands in the 2000s, combining the older style of Bubbling with more modern House, especially Dutch House.

children.name: Changa tuki
children.description: Emerged in Caracas; highly influenced by 1990s Techno and Tribal House, featuring fast tempos, strident synthesizers, hard-thumping percussion lines, and plenty of breakbeats.

children.name: Chicago Hard House
children.description: Originated from Chicago around the mid-1990s as a development of Ghetto House, emphasizing hard-hitting, off-beat drum patterns, fast tempos, and lack of melodies.

children.name: LA Hard House
children.description: Distorted, minimalistic TR-909 derived rhythms, basic climaxing structures and heavy reliance on high-pitched synthesizer / hoover sounds.

children.name: Chicago House
children.description: Umbrella term for a broad variety of House that originated from Chicago in the (mostly mid-to-late) 1980s and early 90s.

children.name: Deep House
children.description: Emerged in the United States during the mid-1980s, featuring a relaxed tempo and influences from Jazz, Funk, and Soul.

children.name: Lo-Fi House
children.description: Primarily distinguished from earlier styles of outsider house by its stricter reliance on deep house elements, cranky, nocturnal, and nostalgic atmospheres, and a distinct dreamy, lo-fi aesthetic.

children.name: Diva House
children.description: Dominant, anthemic female vocals, common use of piano stabs, and energetic, driving four-on-the-floor rhythms.

children.name: Hardbag
children.description: Development of handbag / Diva House characterized by heavier, hard hitting percussion, more pronounced rave and early Hard Dance elements, and fewer vocals.

children.name: Electro House
children.description: Warm analog basslines, punchy percussion, crisp high-pitched synthesizer leads, and clipped vocal samples.

children.name: Complextro
children.description: Features densely-layered sound design, fast-paced cut-up sections, aggressive stabs, and common crossover with Brostep and Fidget House.

children.name: Dutch House
children.description: High-pitched wonky synth melodies and heavy influence from Fidget House which developed in the Netherlands around 2007-08.

children.name: Fidget House
children.description: Makes heavy use of Breakbeat Hardcore-esque synth stabs, pitch bending of basslines, and cut-up vocal samples, as well as glitchy, or "choppy", 4/4 rhythms.

children.name: French Electro
children.description: Mixes Electro House with major elements of genres such as Electroclash, Nu-Disco, Synth Funk, and even Electro-Industrial, resulting in a harsh, punchy, and funky midtempo sound.

children.name: Melbourne Bounce
children.description: Offbeat basslines giving it a "bouncy" groove, and minimalistic, side-chained melodies often making use of Dutch House-influenced synths, horns or vocal chops, resulting in a flippant, party-oriented atmosphere.

children.name: Euro House
children.description: Vocal-focused style emerging in the late 1980s in Europe, developing in parallel with Eurodance.

children.name: Hardbag
children.description: Development of handbag / Diva House characterized by heavier, hard hitting percussion, more pronounced rave and early Hard Dance elements, and fewer vocals.

children.name: Festival Progressive House
children.description: Uplifting, melodic, energetic but clean drops, featuring modern supersaws and pianos, taking influences from Progressive House, Uplifting Trance, but applying them to a form structurally closer to Big Room House and Electro House.

children.name: French House
children.description: Originated in France in the mid-1990s, characterized by the use of filtered (low-pass, phaser, etc.) samples of Funk and Disco.

children.name: Funky House
children.description: Funky, warm, catchy basslines on top of looped Funk or Disco samples, resulting in an upbeat, bouncy, and pacy groove.

children.name: Future Funk
children.description: Sample-based form of House which formed out of Vaporwave in the early 2010s.

children.name: Future House
children.description: Features distinctive metallic-sounding drops and frequency-modulated basslines at around 120-130 BPM.

children.name: Future Bounce
children.description: Fusion of Melbourne Bounce and Future House that combines the former's basslines and bouncy, upbeat drops with the latter's metallic, pronounced synth leads.

children.name: Slap House
children.description: Taking influences from Brazilian Bass and Future House, characterized by prominent, "bouncy" bassline and simple, upbeat melodies.

children.name: Garage House
children.description: Disco-influenced style of House that developed in the 1980s, incorporating elements of Gospel, Soul, and Dub, before evolving into a more upbeat style that prominently features crisp syncopated hi-hats and synth stabs.

children.name: Gospel House
children.description: Incorporates heavy Gospel elements and singing borrowed from classic and contemporary gospel, usually in the form of choir vocals and call-and-response chants.

children.name: Jersey Sound
children.description: Soulful, melodic, Gospel-infused House music developed in Newark, NJ in the late 1980s and early 1990s with an emphasis on songcraft.

children.name: Ghetto House
children.description: Rough sound based around minimal drum machine-driven tracks and heavy usage of vocal samples.

children.name: Juke
children.description: Faster than Ghetto House, playing at 160bpm, and makes striking use of unconventional drum patterns which differ wildly from other house styles.

children.name: G-House
children.description: Deep, dark form of House music that primarily incorporates rap samples or original rapping on top of minimal, bassy beats.

children.name: Gqom
children.description: Evolved from South African House, specifically Kwaito; often described as a more minimal and raw version.

children.name: Hip House
children.description: Incorporates production elements of early Hip Hop and usually rapping into 1980s House.

children.name: Italo House
children.description: Originated in Italy during the late 1980s, making use of anthemic pianos, diva vocals, and Dance-Pop song structures.

children.name: Jackin' House
children.description: Punchy, 'shuffly' percussion, strong grooves, funky basslines, and chopped-up samples.

children.name: Kwaito
children.description: Emerged from South Africa in the early 1990s, taking influence from Disco and Hip Hop.

children.name: Latin House
children.description: Emerged in the second half of the 1980s, blending four-on-the-floor beats with Hispanic American Music influences from Puerto Rico, Mexico, Cuba, Dominica, and Colombia.

children.name: Microhouse
children.description: Stripped-down, minimal form of House, originating in the late 90s, which takes influence from Minimal Techno, Glitch and IDM.

children.name: Organic House
children.description: Subtle drums and grooves, slow tempos, and acoustic, traditional instrumentation, resulting in an organic, warm sound and spiritual atmosphere.

children.name: Outsider House
children.description: Mostly derived from Deep House; intentional use of rough, lo-fi production, often utilizing a mix of analog/analog-like and digital instrumentation.

children.name: Lo-Fi House
children.description: Primarily distinguished from earlier styles of outsider house by its stricter reliance on deep house elements, cranky, nocturnal, and nostalgic atmospheres, and a distinct dreamy, lo-fi aesthetic.

children.name: Phonk House
children.description: Merges Drift Phonk's nocturnal atmospheres, cowbell melodies, vocal samples, and energetic production, with House rhythms and tempos, characterized by a banging and upbeat sound.

children.name: Progressive House
children.description: Trance-influenced strain of House that grew to prominence in the early 1990s, using polished production and gradual progressions.

children.name: Romanian Popcorn
children.description: Emerged in the second half of the 2000s in Romania, often featuring brass melodies and "staccato" pluck grooves.

children.name: Speed Garage
children.description: Primarily British style that paved the way for UK Garage, combining cut-up vocal samples and sped up four-on-the-floor Garage House rhythms with Jungle-esque basslines.

children.name: Tech House
children.description: Emerged in the mid-1990s taking influences from Techno, broadly characterized by minimalistic and repetitive melodies, focus on the bassline, and constant groove recognizable by prominent off-beat hi-hats.

children.name: Deep Tech
children.description: Incorporates UK Garage rhythms and synths stabs, influences from British rave music, UK Bass and UK Deep House, resulting in an urban, subdued, but danceable sound with deep, muted basslines.

children.name: Rominimal
children.description: Hypnotic, minimal, and "dubby" loops, featuring subtle and intricate synth pads, cranky, clicky percussion, and bouncy, pulsing basslines.

children.name: Tribal House
children.description: Prominent, syncopated rhythms of tribal drums such as toms and bongos on top of a House beat, usually resulting in a percussive, energetic sound, while ranging in mood.

children.name: Guaracha [EDM]
children.description: Originated in Colombia, featuring "fluttering" trumpets, accordion, and tambora drums.

children.name: Tropical House
children.description: Offshoot of Deep House featuring slow tempos around 100-115 BPM, light percussion and acoustic instrumentation, setting out to create a relaxed, summery, beach-like atmosphere.

children.name: UK Hard House
children.description: Defined by offbeat bass patterns, compressed 909-style drums, buildup-drop structures, hoover sounds, and tempos between 120 and 155 BPM.

children.name: Scouse House
children.description: Features an upbeat and energetic sound often described as being "bouncy", influenced somewhat by Happy Hardcore.

children.name: Hardbass
children.description: Bouncy hard bass beats, fast tempo, usually 150-175 BPM, and occasional lyrics or rapping.

children.name: Speed House
children.description: Mixes busy, dirty sound design and intense drums derived from Bass House with fast tempos from 140-160 BPM, pumping basslines, and other UK Hard House influences.

children.name: UK Jackin'
children.description: Successor to British Bassline, characterized by strong basslines, dark atmospheres, and dominant grooves.

children.name: Vinahouse
children.description: Fast-paced House popular in Vietnam, remixing Vietnamese melodies.

children.name: Hyper Techno
children.description: Exaggerated fast form of Belgian Techno for the Japanese market, focusing mainly on synth sounds and samples typical of 1990s dance music.

children.name: Jungle Terror
children.description: Emerging mostly from Dutch House and Big Room House, incorporates Tribal House-influenced percussion, hard kicks, and animal sounds resulting in a wild, jungle-resembling atmosphere in a festival EDM-oriented context.

children.name: Kuduro
children.description: Angolan music combining traditional Kilapanga and Semba with Techno and House.

children.name: Batida
children.description: Initially developed in the late '80s in Luanda, Angola, as a mixture of Soca- and Zouk-based percussion samples.

children.name: Makina
children.description: Spanish Techno developed in the early 1990s; strongly influenced by New Beat and EBM, but aiming for a lighter sound.

children.name: Manyao
children.description: Asian Electronic Dance Music that mixes vocals and melodies from Mandopop with fairly hard, melodic EDM.

children.name: Midtempo Bass
children.description: Harsh synth leads and a usual tempo of around 90-110 BPM.

children.name: Moombahcore
children.description: Characterized by high-pitched synth leads, gritty percussion, a kick-snare pattern, aggressive bass drops, and around 110 BPM while often paralleling Complextro or Brostep.

children.name: Moombahton
children.description: Offshoot of Dutch House characterized by tempos in the 100-110 BPM range, Reggaetón-influenced rhythms, bass-heavy kicks and high-pitched synths.

children.name: Nerdcore Techno
children.description: Stylistically diverse form of underground Japanese Electronic Dance Music utilizing energetic beats built around samples from pop and/or nerd culture.

children.name: Nu-Disco
children.description: 21st-century trend mixing modern, polished Electronic production with the aesthetics, structures, and lively, organic beats of 1970s and 1980s Disco.

children.name: Ori deck
children.description: Incorporates elements of Moombahton and Dubstep to create a style characterized by sluggish, kick-heavy dembow rhythms.

children.name: Shangaan Electro
children.description: South African genre with very fast BPM (around 180) featuring MIDI keyboard sounds and marimba.

children.name: Singeli
children.description: Developed in Tanzania in the mid-2000s; fuses incredibly rapid beats, usually between 180-300BPM, with MCing and musical influences from older Tanzanian genres.

children.name: Techno
children.description: Highly beat-driven, repetitive, and mechanical, typically featuring minimal chord variation and melodies, focuses on rhythms and timbral variety; generally produced for club environments.

children.name: Acid Techno
children.description: Incorporates "squelching" synths from Acid House into a mechanical and usually more energetic Techno context.

children.name: Ambient Techno
children.description: Blends the mechanical, repetitive beats of Techno with atmospheres and textures inspired by Ambient music, resulting in slower tempos and more understated rhythms.

children.name: Belgian Techno
children.description: Early form of Hardcore [EDM], resulting from the further evolution of New Beat due to the strong influence of Techno and EBM.

children.name: Bleep Techno
children.description: Established in the late 1980s in the breakdancing and early rave scene of Yorkshire in the North of England, notable for its "bleepy" synth lines and heavy sub-bass.

children.name: Detroit Techno
children.description: Features a signature mechanical, detached sound that echoed the atmosphere of Detroit's nightlife and incorporated influences from Electro, Chicago House, as well as Synthpop and Electro-Disco.

children.name: Freetekno
children.description: Originated in the early 1990s, commonly played at free parties in Europe, and features a repetitive pounding kick drum at tempos of 170 BPM or above.

children.name: Hardgroove Techno
children.description: Popular in the early 2000s; features layered shuffling percussion.

children.name: Hard Techno
children.description: Typically rave-oriented form characterized by hard, prominent kick drums, pounding rhythms, fast tempos around 140-160 BPM, and aggressive, often distorted sounds.

children.name: Schranz
children.description: Characterised by fast tempos, aggressive "whooshing" beat patterns, heavy compression and straightforward song structures.

children.name: Industrial Techno
children.description: Harder, darker style of Techno which draws parallels with factories and the rhythm of machinery.

children.name: Birmingham Sound
children.description: Cold, mechanical, and hypnotic tracks, typically lacking the harsher and noisier elements of later Industrial Techno.

children.name: Melodic Techno
children.description: Trance-influenced subgenre that was established in the mid-to-late 2010s, characterized by gradually progressing structure, and hypnotizing, atmospheric sound with arpeggiated, minor melodies, playing at around 120-125 BPM.

children.name: Minimal Techno
children.description: Stripped-down and sparse, often featuring a dark sound and a slow, steady development through the track.

children.name: Dub Techno
children.description: Fuses elements of Minimal Techno with characteristics of Dub.

children.name: Peak Time Techno
children.description: Hard, dynamic, energetic and accessible subgenre featuring strong kicks, massive dirty synths, tempos around 130 BPM, more suspenseful structures with breaks and build-ups, and big, modern, festival-oriented sound; rose to high popularity in the late 2010s.

children.name: Wonky Techno
children.description: Strays from the standard beat of Techno, opting for a more fractured sound.

children.name: Techno Bass
children.description: Minimal, stripped-down with an emphasis on low-frequency bass partitions.

children.name: Tecnorumba
children.description: Blend of the themes and singing style of Rumba flamenca with the most commercial forms of House, Techno, and Makina.

children.name: Trance
children.description: Evolving, tension-building structures with rapid, minor arpeggios on top of a hypnotic, four-on-the-floor drum patterns at fast tempo around 130-150 BPM.

children.name: Acid Trance
children.description: Incorporates "squelching" acid basslines into Trance's evolving structure.

children.name: Big Room Trance
children.description: Incorporates production features associated with Big Room House and dirty, distorted leads influenced by Electro House, Dutch House and Hardstyle.

children.name: Dream Trance
children.description: Slow tempo (about 130 BPM) with strong roots in Progressive House, using beats typical of Eurodance and Dance-Pop; emphasizes a laid-back, carefree, and dreamlike sound.

children.name: Euro-Trance
children.description: More accessible, usually vocal-driven subgenre that emerged as a fusion with Eurodance, featuring its catchy, upbeat melodies and offbeat basslines while keeping the fast tempos.

children.name: Hands Up
children.description: Prominent, melodic supersaw leads, Dance-Pop derived hooks, and a strong reliance on sidechained basslines and hard, powerful drums.

children.name: Hard Trance
children.description: Rave-oriented form of Trance infusing its atmospheres with faster, thumping rhythms and strong melodic / bassline sections, initially spawning out of the first wave in early-1990s Western Europe.

children.name: Ibiza Trance
children.description: Builds on the relaxing island atmosphere of Balearic Beat, though with a slightly faster tempo of around 130 BPM.

children.name: NRG
children.description: Derived from UK Hard House; featuring darker, more anthemic Trance beats and a tempo of 155-165 BPM.

children.name: Progressive Trance
children.description: Combination of Trance and Progressive House which emerged in Western Europe in the early to mid-1990s.

children.name: Psytrance
children.description: Trance with a psychedelic feel and energetic sound, based around influences from Goa Trance and Acid Trance.

children.name: Dark Psytrance
children.description: Dark, fast and Industrial-influenced.

children.name: Hi-Tech Psytrance
children.description: Glitchy sound design, morphing synth lines, strange sounds typically evoking futuristic or alien-like atmospheres, and faster tempos than most other forms of Psytrance.

children.name: Psycore
children.description: Pushes the dark atmospheres of Dark Psytrance to the extreme through the usage of exceptionally high tempos and experimental soundscapes influenced by Dark Ambient and Glitch.

children.name: Forest Psytrance
children.description: Mimicks the ambience of a forest by using swarming and teeming effects as well as natural samples; features straightforward song structures.

children.name: Full-On Psytrance
children.description: Faster, more intense form of Psytrance usually around 145-150 BPM using harder basslines, regular vocal samples, and "spacey" effects.

children.name: Goa Trance
children.description: Forerunner of Psytrance styles that emerged in the early 1990s, distinguished by old-school, organic sound with rapid, oriental-inspired melodies.

children.name: Nitzhonot
children.description: Fast-paced and melodic, uses pulsating basses and hard and often high-pitched kicks.

children.name: Progressive Psytrance
children.description: Emerged in the early 2000s, featuring a slow tempo range and clean production.

children.name: Zenonesque
children.description: Experimental and leftfield approach to Progressive Psytrance, mixing the atmospheric and clean Psytrance production typical of it with funky and jazzy elements.

children.name: Suomisaundi
children.description: Finnish-based deviation of Psytrance with an emphasis on free-form experimentation and humor.

children.name: Tech Trance
children.description: Late 1990s-emerging subgenre characterized by energetic percussion with loud kicks, filtered hi-hats and tribal drums; side-chained, detuned and repetitive leads, as well as other raw, distorted, and complex sounds influenced by Techno, Hard Trance and Electro House.

children.name: Uplifting Trance
children.description: Euphoric melodies, buildup-breakdown-anthem structures, common usage of supersaws, and a BPM range of usually around 135-142.

children.name: Vocal Trance
children.description: Melodic, polished, Pop-like, and vocal-focused with around 120-145 BPM and frequent overlap with Progressive Trance, Uplifting Trance, and Euro-Trance.

children.name: Trap [EDM]
children.description: Trap-influenced syncopated percussion with 808 samples and fast-paced hi-hats.

children.name: Festival Trap
children.description: Massive, sub-bass-heavy drops with simple melodies, synth leads and production influenced by Big Room House; highly popular from 2013 to 2015.

children.name: Hard Trap
children.description: Often abrasive subgenre of Trap [EDM] with heavy influence from Hardstyle.

children.name: Heaven Trap
children.description: Blends Trap [EDM]’s signature percussion and sub-basses with euphoric, uplifting, melodious drops prominently derived from Festival Progressive House, contrary to the gritty, "dirty" nature of other EDM trap styles.

children.name: Hybrid Trap
children.description: Blending Trap [EDM]'s typical percussion and sub-basses with major influences from heavy bass music genres, and in particular, metallic, gritty, and off-kilter sound design, originally derived from Brostep.

children.name: Twerk
children.description: Fast-paced; draws influence from Bounce and Miami Bass.

children.name: Tribal Guarachero
children.description: Features percussion from Cumbia and Mexican Folk Music with upbeat Electro House-derived production and fast, triplet-oriented rhythmic patterns.

children.name: UK Bass
children.description: Broad form of Electronic Dance Music characterized by prominent bass/sub-basses, a deep, dark, airy, and mechanical sound derived from Dubstep, and eclectic production influenced by UK Funky, Juke/Footwork, Techno, and Breakbeat.

children.name: UK Funky
children.description: Influenced by UK Garage-related styles and the regional styles of British immigrants, including Soca and West African-inspired Tribal House.

children.name: UK Garage
children.description: Shuffling rhythms and influences from sources including Contemporary R&B and Hip Hop, as well as many forms of Electronic.

children.name: 2-Step
children.description: Originating in London and popular in the late 1990s; jittery, shuffling rhythms rarely following a four-on-the-floor pattern.

children.name: Bassline
children.description: Strong emphasis on intricate basslines as well as four-on-the-floor beat patterns.

children.name: Breakstep
children.description: Differentiated from other UK Garage subgenres by its use of hard-hitting Breakbeat rhythms, as well as its focus on heavy, rolling basslines.

children.name: Future Garage
children.description: Derivative of UK Garage combining influences from the rhythms of late 1990s and early 2000s 2-Step with novel moods and production approaches, commonly featuring jittery, broken rhythms, vocal chops, and warm synth pads and plucks.

children.name: Speed Garage
children.description: Primarily British style that paved the way for UK Garage, combining cut-up vocal samples and sped up four-on-the-floor Garage House rhythms with Jungle-esque basslines.

children.name: Wonky
children.description: Off-kilter fusion of Dubstep and Hip Hop which first developed in the mid-to-late 2000s.

children.name: Aquacrunk
children.description: Syncopated, half-time rhythms inspired by Dubstep and Grime, funky, sludgy, "aquatic"-sounding synths and sound design.

name: Electropop
description: Dense, layered, and compressed production, usually coupled with a distinct fuzzy and "warm" low-frequency synthesizer style.

name: Epic Collage
description: Defined by its Deconstructed Club sonic palette and its cinematic proportions.

name: Flashcore
description: Intense wandering soundscapes, scattered rapid short-duration sounds, complex avant-garde structures, and, usually, layered acousmatic decomposition and influences from Speedcore, IDM, and Breakcore.

name: Folktronica
description: Combines sound design techniques from IDM and Glitch with acoustic instrumentation inspired by Contemporary Folk.

name: Funktronica
description: Originated in eastern North America around the turn of the 21st century, combining trends of Synth Funk and Italo-Disco.

name: Glitch
description: Uses the sounds created by malfunctioning digital technology - crashes, hardware noise, CD skipping, and digital distortion - for composition.

name: Glitch Hop
description: Incorporation of IDM-derived production into drum patterns inspired by Hip Hop beats.

name: HexD
description: Heavily bit-crushed vocals, sometimes sped-up and pitched-up, and highly compressed and distorted production, typically made from existing material of other genres.

name: Horror Synth
description: Combines eerie and haunting synth pads and sharp, abrasive sounds to create atmospheres that accentuated the dark, unnerving, violent, or ghostly themes of horror films.

name: Hyperpop
description: Developed and took inspiration from Bubblegum Bass and popular 2000s-2010s Electropop, characterized by eclectic, unconventional, mechanical-sounding and dense production; and by manipulated, usually auto-tuned vocals.

name: IDM
description: Emerged through the development of Electronic Dance Music idioms into a less club-oriented and more experimental direction, often incorporating unconventional sound design and complex rhythms.

children.name: Drill and Bass
children.description: Frenzied, intricate beat programming inspired by Drum and Bass.

name: Illbient
description: Combines Ambient soundscapes with Hip Hop drum patterns, breaks, and samples through the busy effect layering of Dub.

name: Indietronica
description: Leftfield or DIY approach characterised by simpler Pop-informed melodies, often incorporating vocals or live instrumentation alongside Electronic production.

children.name: Chillwave
children.description: Emulates vintage aesthetics and popular musical styles of the 1980s/1990s altered by modern recording technology to create a hazy dreamlike atmosphere.

children.name: Chillsynth
children.description: Mixes Synthwave with major Chillwave elements, characterized by a dreamy and relaxed sound.

children.name: Glitch Pop
children.description: Incorporates elements of more experimental Electronic styles like IDM and Glitch.

children.name: Picopop
children.description: Originated in the early 2000s as an offshoot of the Japanese Shibuya-kei movement when artists introduced more prominent "bleepy" electronic elements and faster tempos.

name: Latin Electronic
description: Combines Electronic with Latin American influences; started at the end of the 1990s.

children.name: Changa tuki
children.description: Emerged in Caracas; highly influenced by 1990s Techno and Tribal House, featuring fast tempos, strident synthesizers, hard-thumping percussion lines, and plenty of breakbeats.

children.name: Digital Cumbia
children.description: Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.

children.name: Electro latino
children.description: Mixes elements of Merengue and Reggaetón with polished production from mainstream House subgenres; often shares traits with Latin Pop, having anthemic melodies and verse-chorus structures.

children.name: Electrotango
children.description: Combines Tango rhythms and melodies with Electronic music.

children.name: Nortec
children.description: Samples and synthesizes Mexican styles like Banda sinaloense and Norteño into a sound related to IDM and House.

children.name: Tribal Guarachero
children.description: Features percussion from Cumbia and Mexican Folk Music with upbeat Electro House-derived production and fast, triplet-oriented rhythmic patterns.

name: Livetronica
description: Incorporates Electronic instrumentation into live Rock jamming, drawing on a wide variety of Electronic Dance Music and Downtempo styles.

name: Microsound
description: Usage of sounds on an incredibly small scale.

name: Minatory
description: Extreme, experimental style forked from Deathstep, with a harsh sound and sudden BPM changes.

name: Minimal Wave
description: Retrospective term for more Electronic and minimal forms of New Wave, Post-Punk, Synthpop, and related styles, tending towards a more sparse and lo-fi sound.

children.name: Minimal Synth
children.description: Minimal and distinctly DIY take on Synthpop with a bleak and naive aesthetic.

name: Moogsploitation
description: Moog-led Electronic music often associated with a wave of Novelty records in the 1960s and 1970s.

name: Nightcore
description: Based around the technique of speeding and pitching up already existing songs.

name: Nu Jazz
description: Electronic styles which feature aesthetics and occasionally instrumentation inspired by Jazz.

name: Power Electronics
description: Waves of feedback, screeching analog synthesizers, and harsh, screamed vocals.

children.name: Death Industrial
children.description: Combines the abrasive textures of Noise and Industrial music with dark, brooding drones and atmospheres.

name: Power Noise
description: Combines looped samples of Noise with Electronic rhythms.

name: Progressive Electronic
description: Synthesizer-driven genre focusing on developing, often longform compositions and drawing inspiration from various sources such as Progressive Rock, Western Classical Music, and Ambient.

children.name: Berlin School
children.description: Atmospheric, multi-layered synthesizer textures; pioneered in Berlin in the 1970s as an offshoot to the Krautrock movement.

name: Space Ambient
description: Flowing and relaxing synthesizer-based music derived from Progressive Electronic, often oriented around imagery of outer space.

name: Synthpop
description: Led by a prominent, melodic synthesizer sound, often with reverberated drum machine patterns that create a distinct atmospheric feel commonly associated with the 1980s.

children.name: Futurepop
children.description: Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.

children.name: Pon-chak disco
children.description: Heavily influenced by Electro-Disco, featuring cheap "electronic organ" synth leads and minimalistic, repetitive rhythms.

children.name: Techno kayō
children.description: Offshoot of 1980s Kayōkyoku and Idol kayō incorporating characteristics from Synthpop.

name: Synth Punk
description: Appropriates the harsh elements of Punk Rock but replaces the predominance of guitars with synthesizers and drum machines.

name: Synthwave
description: Rooted in 1980s synth music, characterized by large, throbbing "retro" synths and visual elements, often features upbeat percussion and/or epic, cinematic atmospheres.

children.name: Chillsynth
children.description: Mixes Synthwave with major Chillwave elements, characterized by a dreamy and relaxed sound.

children.name: Darksynth
children.description: Incorporates atmospheric Horror Synth and faster tempos into a much heavier and darker sound.

name: Tecnobrega
description: Fast and electronic-based style that evolved from Brega calypso, particularly associated with peripheral areas of the city of Belém.

children.name: Tecnofunk
children.description: Raw and vulgar Tecnobrega and Funk brasileiro fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.

name: Vapor
description: Meta-genre beginning with the rise of Vaporwave and the aesthetics that it spawned.

children.name: Barber Beats
children.description: Borrows elements from Downtempo, Trip Hop, and Instrumental Hip Hop; emulates 1990s and 2000s Chillout music.

children.name: Dreampunk
children.description: Accentuates ambiance and a dreamy atmosphere within Vapor.

children.name: Future Funk
children.description: Sample-based form of House which formed out of Vaporwave in the early 2010s.

children.name: Hardvapour
children.description: Influenced by Hardcore [EDM] and Techno and made in response to the Vaporwave movement.

children.name: Utopian Virtual
children.description: Born out of Hypnagogic Pop that emulates late 20th century futuristic and corporate aesthetics, often using "tacky"-sounding MIDI-esque instruments, in contrast to the looping, sample-based approach generally found in Vaporwave.

children.name: Vaportrap
children.description: Incorporates a blend of Trap percussion set to the re-utilization of old samples, such as 1990s pop culture or old computer library sounds.

children.name: Vaporwave
children.description: Sample-based, involves heavily synthesized and processed manipulation of corporate mood and background (elevator) music; though source material can also include genres such as Pop, Contemporary R&B, and Synth Funk.

children.name: Broken Transmission
children.description: Uses samples taken from TV broadcasts, advertising, film, radio, and other sources - often slowing down and manipulating the sound heavily.

children.name: Mallsoft
children.description: Blends the main characteristics of Vaporwave with what can be described as background/elevator music.

children.name: Slushwave
children.description: Specializes in a distinct form of sample manipulation rooted in Vaporwave, heavily utilizing multi-layered effects to create a specific "slushy", hypnagogic sound usually sequenced in soft, repetitive Ambient-based soundscapes.

name: Wave
description: Heavily influenced by 2010s Hip Hop production, characterized by dark, icy, nocturnal, and melancholic beats.

children.name: Hardwave
children.description: Harder, festival-oriented offshoot of Wave, combining its "reese" basses and icy synths with Trap [EDM] drum patterns, build-up-drop structures, and fuller sound influenced by Trance and Hardstyle.

children.name: Neo-Grime
children.description: Mixes Wave with Grime and other forms of UK Electronic music.

name: Witch House
description: Nocturnal, occult-themed/horror-inspired, and murky beats with altered, slowed down and heavily processed samples laid on top of slow Hip Hop-derived drum rhythms and droning, dense synthesizers.
